content.description: The crux for me was “threading the needle” behind the tree and next move or two. Be aware of dead limbs atop this larger birch I put my back against the tree to rest and top limbs were bouncing as if they might fall soon.
content.location: Left and slightly uphill from Mother’s Day.

content.description: Fun route with varied climbing. Pretty vertical, thus pumpy, so use the good jams. Multiple cruxes throughout, including bouldery topout, but all are well-protected.
content.protection: cams to 3", mid-range doubles. anchor on pine trees. no fixed gear.
content.location: Route is obvious crack and shelf system at far left side of second face from the highway. 3rd class to short slab with multi-finger pockets and work up to the left of large roof. Bouldery top-out leads to pine trees at top. Avoid rapping the trees to preserve them and walk off. See beta photo.

content.protection: Small cams and nuts. Tricky and sparse.
content.location: Start at far right side of second face from highway. Climb corner adjacent to bouldering rock. Follow up right angling cracks to top. Try not to use adjacent rock.

content.description: 2 poorly protected crux moves, one of which is low, make this a good TR. Some awkward stuff, some cool stuff. Tenuous and bouldery movement. Try not to use your knees. Many variations for finish.
content.protection: Cams and nuts to 2". Anchor on pine trees. No fixed gear.
content.location: Start in dirty corner as for Little League and haul up left onto small ramp. Continue up left with bad pro to good hand/finger crack, then up right to finish.

content.description: Climb the aret and use Slab/ friction technique. Trending mostly straight up and slightly left toward overlap and continuing straight up or slightly left more pro to the left.
content.protection: Rack to 3” some doubles in .3 to .75 maybe
content.location: Walking from baseball/ soccer field follow trail into woods take a left when the stone wall breaks. Walk along bottom of cliff/slab and look for large pine tree growing out of a crack 20 or so feet up the slab.

content.description: This wall offers some mid-range Trad Climbing on high-quality rock.
